text: EconLog | Menu FEATURED POST Dec 3 2018 POPULISM Categories: Behavioral Economics, Cost-beneï¬t Analysis, Microeconomics, Political Economy SHARE POST: Almost every psychologically normal human is delighted to hear about products everyone can enjoy free of charge.Â  â€œThe schools are free!â€Â  â€œHealth care is free!â€Â  â€œLunch is free!â€ According to basic welfare economics, however, gratis goods areÂ almost automatically inefficient.Â  Unless the marginal social cost of the product miraculously happens to be zero, setting a price of zero leads to socially wasteful behavior. A better story is that people are taking transactions costs into account.Â  Free is almost never first-best efficient, but it can easily be second-best efficient.Â  Suppose, for example, that the marginal social cost of adding another car to the road is $.75, but the cost of collecting a toll is $1.00.Â  On balance, itâ€™s less inefficient to let people drive for free than impose marginal cost pricing. On reflection, however, this story is also quite weak.Â  If it were true, people would be pro-gratis for products that are cheap to produce.Â  In reality, however, what most excites and delights mankind is gratis products that areÂ expensive to produce.Â  Free health care and free education are far more popular than free toothpicks. But this story, too, is shaky.Â  Empirically, itâ€™s far from clear that means-tested programs are markedly less popular or politically stable than universal programs.Â  Whatever their subtle disadvantages, means-tested programs have an obvious advantage: Helping the needy is far cheaper than helping everyone.Â  Finally, if it really were true that we have to help everyone to help anyone, that would be a potent argument against helping anyone!Â Â As I explained a while back: Economists habitually mock protectionism for its high cost-benefit ratio.Â  â€œ$265,000 per job saved!Â  How ridiculous.â€â€¦ Notice, however, that we can easily ridicule universal social programs in exactly the same way that we ridicule protectionism.Â  Suppose two-thirds of the population is perfectly able to provide for its own retirement and health insurance.Â  Then the budgetary cost of cloaking welfare for the bottom one-third in universal garb isÂ triple the apparent cost.Â  And that ignores all the disincentive effects of the extra taxes and giveaways.Â  Add it all up, and you could easily get a number in the protectionist ballpark.Â  Think: â€œ$100,000 per retiree lifted out of poverty!Â  How ridiculous.â€ Even if Iâ€™m wrong here, the â€œMake goods free in order to redistribute with dignity in a politically palatable wayâ€ argument is far too sophisticated to explain popular affection for gratis goods.Â  So what does explain this affection?
